subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Re: Lexical sets and QS letters
msgSnippet: ... See below. ... I m not sure what you mean. At first I thought you meant that many speakers don t pronounce the Yo-yo before Awl, but now I m not sure
messageBody:
Anthony Grahn wrote:
>
>
> I've grayed out several more lexical groups (so to speak) to allow
> CLOTH, THOUGHT, LOT, PALM permutations and NEAR, KIT, FLEECE. I'm
> concerned that #32, #33, #39 have no "black" lexical groups and how
> anyone but the chart's author could ever figure out what the letters
> #32, #33, #39 should be used for.

See below.

>
> http://groups.yahoo.com/group/Read_Alphabet/files/Pronunciation/fig1.jpg
> <http://groups.yahoo.com/group/Read_Alphabet/files/Pronunciation/fig1.jpg>
>
> Alas, going down this path is starting to cause some oddities.
>
> - The CURE merge with THOUGHT/NORTH/FORCE would have to be done under
> #33. But could anyone in America read Key+Ye+Awe+Roe as the word "cure"

I'm not sure what you mean. At first I thought you meant that many
speakers don't pronounce the "Yo-yo" before "Awl," but now I'm not sure
if you don't mean the problem lies with the vowel "Awl." For the record,
I do pronounce "cure" in that way, but I'm from Boston and don't have a
TV accent.

>
> - Allowing the TRAP-LOT merger looks like it will make #30 unintelligible.
>
> Anyone have an idea about these?

I'm not sure why we want to merge TRAP-LOT


>
> If we can use lexical groups to pre build a list of sample words for
> each QS letter for every accent and post that prominently then we
> would be in absolutely great shape.
> - we would not need any IPA charts
> - we would not have to worry about massively complex explanations
> about moving gray words around. Only the authors of the pre built
> charts would have to know them.

Yes, I think this is the way to go. I think right now the problem with
the chart is that it tries to show too much, to cover all instances in a
general way. I think at this point you might want to make a specific
chart, say for your own dialect. We can then look at problematic sets,
or words, and try to figure out how to handle the problem. We can then
move to other regions of the US, and then we can move across the ocean.

For me, the problem in figuring this out is trying to understand so many
lexical sets that can be moved around--it seems so abstract at this
point that I can't really address the problem. For example, you probably
have a good reason for thinking that LOT and TRAP will have to be merged
under certain circumstances, but I'm trying to think how and when, which
in turn probably doesn't make my responses very helpful.

You had mentioned that you wanted to ask posters about how they
pronounced different words. I think maybe we could start doing this, but
rather than the way you proposed, maybe we could ask something like "How
many posters pronounce "On" and "Thought" with the same vowel?" Or "What
groups of words belong together?" Actually, thinking aloud, this second
idea sounds even better. We could take all the lexical words from
problematic sets, mix them up, and then ask users to group them. That
might be the most useful. So say if I email back and say that I group
"beer" and "bear" in the same group, and another user writes back and
says "I could never live with seeing 'beer' and 'bear' written with the
same vowel," then we know we have a problematic merger and we address it.

We also might want to start another thread at this point! This one is
way nested deep in my email program.

Paul
